data.title: (DesktopGL) Process still running after window close
data.body: Well, everything is working ok when starting a new project. But after upgrading an existing one to 3.6 process is still running after window close, also debugging process in VS2015 doesn't stop. Everything else is working alright. Platform is DesktopGL, running on Windows 10.

data.title: Support for RenderTarget2D multisampling under DirectX.
data.body:
Added RenderTarget2D multisampling for DirectX. Code is based of [this post](http://community.monogame.net/t/quick-overview-how-to-work-with-msaa-directx-too/8570). 

Changes in first commit are

- Multisampled resource is now created
- Added RenderTarget2D field to RenderTarget2D class. It serves as non-multisampled destination for resolving multisampled RT.
- Basic resolving logic

First commit is just to get it working with little consideration to performance. Resolving probably needs to be optimized (resolve only if needed). 

This depends on #5477

data.title: [SDL] Disable XInput so more than 4 controllers can be detected
data.body: ** NEEDS TESTING **

data.title: Can't use more than 4 wireless gamepads [Desktop GL]
data.body:
1.

My game supports up to 8 players at once and I am getting complaints that only 4 wireless controllers are being detected.
I don't have more than 4 wireless controllers to test so I can't confirm what is happening.
I have tried a mix of wireless and different type of wired controllers and could manage to set up 8 players matches.

This is the Steam thread with the complaints in case you want to take a look:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/414370/discussions/0/152391995404760614/

Last player says that even with a mix of Xbox 360 and Xbox One wireless controllers only 4 of them are recognized.
This is pretty big issue for my game since "8 players" is its unique appeal :)

2.

Also I have successfully ported the game to Android and everything works great but on gamepads the dpad is not working. Tried with Xbox 360 and PS4 controllers and they work fine but dpad is not recognized. This is not a big deal, you can still play on left stick, but it would be nice if dpad is working.

Thanks,
Endi

data.title: Changes in how text input is processed or DrawString in 3.6?
data.body:
When I upgraded I started getting errors due to calling DrawString with tab, or backspace characters.  I'm not sure if this is a result of text input being handled differently, or DrawString maybe used to elide those characters on it's own, and now it is up to us?

Not sure if this is bug or feature, anyone have insight?

data.title: WinFormsGameWindow - no ClientSizeChanged event on window state change
data.body:
Hi guys,

I've noticed that in MonoGame 3.6 ClientSizeChanged (for WinFormsGameWindow) is not invoked anymore when window state changes (normal->maximized and vice versa). It worked properly for us at v3.5.

As a workaround for this issue I've changed (in WinFormsGameWindow.cs):
```C#
Form.ResizeEnd += OnResizeEnd;
```
to
```C#
Form.ResizeEnd += OnResizeEnd;
Form.SizeChanged += OnResizeEnd;
```

But that might lead to some side effects...
BTW, I'm using `GraphicsDeviceManager.HardwareModeSwitch = false;`.

Regards!

data.title: Problem with Graphics.PreferMultiSampling
data.body:
Hi guys,

I've noticed that by default if `Graphics.PreferMultiSampling` is set to `true` you're using `32` constant value:
```C#
// always initialize MultiSampleCount to the maximum, if users want to overwrite
// this they have to respond to the PreparingDeviceSettingsEvent and modify
// args.GraphicsDeviceInformation.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleCount
presentationParameters.MultiSampleCount = GraphicsDevice != null
    ? GraphicsDevice.GraphicsCapabilities.MaxMultiSampleCount
    : 32;
```

The problem is that in most cases SharpDX will be unable to create the graphics device with `32` multisampling level (BTW, I have NVIDIA GPU, and it seems to work properly only with `8` max multisampling level). And the exception is very cryptic (as usual with SharpDX):
```SharpDXException: HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: The parameter is incorrect.```

But that exception is catched by MonoGame and this one thrown instead:
```Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.NoSuitableGraphicsDeviceException: Failed to create graphics device!```

So it was a complete mystique to me and required debugging (with using MonoGame source compiled in debug mode) to determine what's going on. Of course I was able to fix this by subscribing to PreparingDeviceSettings and providing proper value to `GraphicsDeviceInformation.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleCount`. But that's not something I wish for other developers to repeat...

I would prefer to have a proper exception thrown instead of using default `32` value which in most cases will lead to these cryptic exceptions. I know it's not that easy because of current architecture, but we definitely need an improvement in that area.
Even using default value `1` for `MaxMultiSampleCount` will be a better option for now. This way no exception is thrown but developer could quite easily see that multisampling is not working and first thought in that case (at least for me) is that multisample count is set to 1.

Regards!

data.title: Unable to load sdl2.dll
data.body:
Trying to switch my monogame stuff from 3.5 to 3.6 and I immediately run into this issue. The only fix I see is copying sdl2.dll from folder where it's installed on my pc.  This shouldn't happen on upgrading to a new version? Just wondering if it is something on my end. I also had two others create an empty monogame 3.6 from a template and they get the exact same error.  


http://i.imgur.com/sjvFHo0.png

data.title: Annoying fullscreen differences between DirectX and OpenGL
data.body:
I'm using MonoGame 3.6 and `GraphicsDeviceManager.HardwareModeSwitch = false;` and having a hard time working out my code for how I want my game to render. Depending on if I'm using DirectX or OpenGL, I get different behaviors.

| Library | Mode | GraphicsDevice.Viewport.Bounds |
| ------- | ----- | ---------------------|
| DirectX | Original window | 640x400 |
| DirectX | To full | 640x400 |
| DirectX | Back to window | 624x361 |
| OpenGL | Original window | 640x400 |
| OpenGL | To full | 1920x1080 |
| OpenGL | Back to window | 640x400 |

As you can see, DirectX misbehaves when coming out of fullscreen, and OpenGL misbehaves when going to fullscreen.

data.title: SpriteBatch AlphaBlend doesn't look the same on OpenGL vs DirectX
data.body:
Using the new 3.6 nuget packages, alphablending sprite (that is a raw PNG file, not sent through the pipeline) calls doesn't look right. Here is my begin

    Global.SpriteBatch.Begin(SpriteSortMode.Deferred, BlendState.AlphaBlend, SamplerState.PointClamp, DepthStencilState.DepthRead, RasterizerState.CullNone);

And here are the results.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2672110/23485127/f18bad6e-fe8e-11e6-8948-cbb64d77145d.png)

To me it looks like on DirectX, it's figuring out the premultiply correctly while opengl doesn't see it and therefore doesn't use it.

data.title: Texture2Ds created at runtime are not always empty
data.body:
If Texture2D instance is created at runtime by a constructor, that instance is not always empty. By empty I mean, not all pixels are transparent black. In XNA I always get an empty texture (tested on Windows only). 

Now I am not sure if this is intended behavior and I was just lucky that my code worked in XNA as [in docs](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/microsoft.xna.framework.graphics.texture2d.texture2d.aspx) it says: 

> Creates an **_uninitialized_** Texture2D resource of the specified dimensions.

So my question is: is this a correct behavior and if it is, what is the fastest way to clear a texture to transparent black (is there faster way than SetData())?

data.title: Improvements to window handling and full screen switches for desktop
data.body:
This makes some improvements to how the GameWindow works:

- Multisampling is supported by the window on initilization. I create a dummy window to create a temporary GraphicsContext to query for multisampling support. I got some weird behaviour though, so would be nice if someone can test that.
- The window position can be set before the native window is instantiated.
- The window title can be set before the native window is instantiated.
- Initializing in full screen mode no longer depends on the internal `applyChanges` method in game. I #iffed out DESKTOPGL for that method so we know it no longer needs it. One step closer to getting rid of it completely.
- Stop listening for SDL Resized event. If it is raised, the SizeChanged event is raised too, so listening to that is sufficient.
- The ClientSizeChanged event is only raised when a user resizes the window (also while resizing, not just when resizing ends but there's no way to distinguish the two with the SDL API), not when it is resized through a back buffer size change.
- The window position is restored after exiting full screen. This is not very stable because SDL raises a bunch of events when entering/exiting full screen and we can't distinguish them from when a user moves the window. Optionally we can check if window position in the event is (0, 0) relative to the current display and assume its a full screen transition and ignore it when it is.
- Window centering now also happens after resizing the backbuffer in stead of just when exiting full screen. This is also not very stable because of the previous issue. Sometimes we detect a window move when
it's because of a full screen switch and afterwards the window will no longer be centered.

I also added some todo's/comments for more intricate stuff like recreating the window when certain presentation parameters change.

data.title: Support SwapChainPanel on W8.1 / WP8.1 and update templates to use SwapChainPanel
data.body:
I found SwapChainBackgroundPanel behaving very unpredictable as I was testing #5520. That makes sense since it comes from W8.0, It wasn't supposed to run in window mode (W10).
(I found a workaround for #5520 out of nowhere , but that was after I had this PR ready! 8-) )

- `SwapChainBackgroundPanel` & `SwapChainPanel` are wrapped into `GenericSwapChainPanel`.
- `SwapChainBackgroundPanel` is still supported on W8.1 to allow easier upgrade from 3.5, the constructor is marked as [Obsolete].
- W8.1 templates are updated to use `SwapChainPanel`.

data.title: [StoreApps/XAML] Run Game Loop and Input on a seperate Thread
data.body:
Fixes mouse, keyboard lag [UAP] touch, rotation lag & freeze (WP8.1).
#4897, #5300, #3948, #3589, #3316, #4105(?).

This probably still has a ton of bugs. It's hard to tell unless you review every line of MG codebase and run extensive tests. Unfortunetly, that's the nature of thread syncronization. I'd prefer to wait until after 3.6 (and a possible 3.6.1 service update) for this PR.

On the other hand #5352 is more predictable and solves 99% of the issues with just a couple of lines.

data.title: Add support for Gamepad AXIS_HAT_XY on Android
data.body:
I am adding gamepad support to my game, and was testing it out on Android. I have an XBOX One S Controller (with bluetooth) that I connected to my Android tablet.

When testing the gamepad via a gamepad tester app from the app store, all buttons / keys worked except the the right trigger (which is an Android mapping issue and unrelated to Monogame). The app did show that the D-PAD actually generates AXIS_HAT_X and AXIS_HAT_Y events on Android, and not the DPAD_UP, DPAD_DOWN etc.

It does not look like Monogame currently supports the AXIS_HAT_XY events for Android (from looking at the code in https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/Input/GamePad.Android.cs ).

It would be great to add support for this which should (mostly) allow the Xbox One S Controller to be usable on Monogame with little to no tweaking / changes.

Thanks.

data.title: #5511 - Enable VertexBuffer/IndexBuffer.GetData() on iOS
data.body: Enable VertexBuffer/IndexBuffer.GetData() on iOS

data.title: Fix texture ValidateParams exception with DXT1/3/5 decompression on Linux
data.body:
When running on Linux without DXT decompression support (such as the Mesa OpenGL software renderer), the code path for decompressing DXT textures on load is hit.  This code currently has a bug where `levelDataSizeInBytes` is passed through to the `SetData` method, but `levelDataSizeInBytes` is not updated after DXT decompression, so the validation which occurs inside Texture2D to check that the element count is correct fails.

@KonajuGames has informed me this code path is likely going away soon, so I'll also be future proofing Protogame to turn off DXT compression for textures in the content pipeline when targeting Linux (since it's not supported everywhere).

data.title: VertexBuffer.GetData() and Index.GetData() not implemented on iOS
data.body:
Hi! 

I think this would be a useful function to implement in iOS. As sometimes it is useful to be able to retrieve the vertices for whatever reason - be it debugging 

I have wanted to contribute to open source software for a while, and I think this is a good place to start.

I read the Contribution guide and the process is something like:
-Create an issue (so nobody duplicates work)
-Create a fork
-Make Changes to fork (DONT STEAL CODE :P)
-Submit pull request.

Hope I didn't miss anything. Bear with me as I may need help as I haven't really used git/github much. I intend to submit a pull request in the next few days with this fix.

There are some other improvements I intent to submit in the future when I get time.

Thanks

-Rufus

data.title: Update installer for VS2017 project templates
data.body: Change back to checking for the existence of the Project Templates folder in My Documents because VS2017 massively changed their registry structure.  Still only works correctly if the user has admin privileges.  May do a separate non-admin installer for templates only at a later date.
